Re: Insulin for surgery?

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎03-23-2012 12:10 PM

mollythed wrote:  I can see no reason to turn down the insulin.  If you think about it, the insulin is absolutely a more nature method of managing blood glucose than any oral meds we might take.  It's the same stuff our body uses.  We may just need a little more.

 

I was first giving insulin seven years ago, after knee replacement surgery.  I was only using metformin at the time.  I am so glad I got the insulin.  It helped me to see how easy and painless the injections were.  Years later, when my own pancreas began giving out and I needed more help than I was getting from metformin and glipizide, I could look back at that experience and be confident that I would do just fine with injecting insulin myself.   

Then I wonder why insulin is NOT the first choice of treatment... Is it more costly?  Are people on insulin also put of high blood pressure pills to protect their heart and kidney.  If you don't take pills, then you wouldn't have to worry about the liver damage in the long run, am I right?  Hmmmm...  I wonder...

Report Inappropriate Content

Re: Insulin for surgery?

‎03-23-2012 12:20 PM

Annie, you have had good answers and a chance to see that there are good reasons for insulin being given after surgery.

 

I am only on orals myself but would have no objection to having the post surgery care nurses administer insulin according to protocol.

 

Others on this board have to deal with steroid treatments which raise their blood glucose and many find that the temporary use of insulin can help them keep closer to normal numbers.

 

And do keep in mind that high blood glucose does mean slower healing time.

 

Good luck with your decision,

Dianne

Dianne

Diagnosed as type 2 in 2005 with an A1c of 9.1

Started with metformin and a low dose of an ARB for blood pressure. Added a sulfonylurea (a med that helps my pancreas produce my own insulin) Also a low dose of Crestor to lower my cholesterol.
After 7 years I could no longer tolerate metformin so am doing my best to keep control with a max dose of the sulfonylurea and lots of walking, some swimming.

ronaka

Re: Insulin for surgery?

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎03-23-2012 01:16 PM

LilMissDaisy wrote:
Then I wonder why insulin is NOT the first choice of treatment... Is it more costly?  Are people on insulin also put of high blood pressure pills to protect their heart and kidney.  If you don't take pills, then you wouldn't have to worry about the liver damage in the long run, am I right?  Hmmmm...  I wonder...

Daisy that is a good question. When you treat diabetes it is most effective when you treat the root cause of the problem. In type 1 diabetes the root cause is lack of insulin. So, it makes most sense to use insulin to treat it.

 

With most type 2 diabetes the root cause is resistance to insulin. There is lots of insulin but it can't be used effectively. So the best treatment is reduction of insulin resistance. Exercise and weight loss are probably the very best ways of doing that. Medications like metformin and Actos work too. Actos/Avandia has some side effect issues that probably keep it as possible choice but not likely preferred. That pretty much only leaves metformin.

 

Drugs that stimulate insulin however do work, as does injected insulin. Many would argue however that it results in higher than normal insulin levels and there may be side effects to that as well. So in the end it is a balance of risks. Most doctors prescribe metformin for type 2, and then supplement it with insulin stimulating drugs or just insulin if metformin is not enough alone.

Ron

Not a doctor, only another T2 diabetic with, unfortunately 11 year experience. Be cautious about accepting advice, including mine, on medical conditions from the internet. It can be a good place to get ideas, but validate them with your doctor and other medical professionals first.

Thanks!  That makes sense to me.

Re: Insulin for surgery?

‎03-23-2012 01:39 PM

I had a partial thyroidectomy several years ago and they gave me insulin afterward.  It's no big deal and certainly won't hurt you.  My glucose went up over 200 post surgery.  Insulin and exercise are the only way to bring down a high quickly.  I seriously doubt that they want you jogging up and down the halls.  :-)  Besides, like someone else here said, nausea is fairly common after anesthesia (I was sick as a dog) so orals aren't going to do you any good anyway.

 

Good luck with your surgery!

Kate, Type 2 since June 2005
Metformin: 500 mg AM/1000 mg PM
Exercise: 30-60 min every day
Last A1c: 6.0

‎03-23-2012 02:28 PM

I've had insulin a few times post-surgery.  They like your BG a little higher pre-surgery as lows are way more dangerous.  I've never felt the shot, nor had any problems at all.

 

I DO, however have a problem with them testing my BG in the first place and now have a bunch of local nurses wiser about doing it painlessly.

 

cheers,

xena




Dx 2008 - A1C 8.6
Current A1C 5.5

‎03-23-2012 05:26 PM

LilMissDaisy wrote:
mollythed wrote:  I can see no reason to turn down the insulin.  If you think about it, the insulin is absolutely a more nature method of managing blood glucose than any oral meds we might take.  It's the same stuff our body uses.  We may just need a little more.

 

I was first giving insulin seven years ago, after knee replacement surgery.  I was only using metformin at the time.  I am so glad I got the insulin.  It helped me to see how easy and painless the injections were.  Years later, when my own pancreas began giving out and I needed more help than I was getting from metformin and glipizide, I could look back at that experience and be confident that I would do just fine with injecting insulin myself.   

Then I wonder why insulin is NOT the first choice of treatment... Is it more costly?  Are people on insulin also put of high blood pressure pills to protect their heart and kidney.  If you don't take pills, then you wouldn't have to worry about the liver damage in the long run, am I right?  Hmmmm...  I wonder...

 

 

Another reason is that most T2's still have some of their natural function going on when first diagnosed.  If one's body kicks out some insulin along with an injection you could end up having quite a hard time figuring things out and end up with a bunch of lows.

 

Tom

 

Diagnosed T2 October, 2009  A1c 6.8
Currently on Metformin ER 1000mg per day
Last A1c 09/21/2013  5.4

Re: Insulin for surgery?

Options

‎03-24-2012 12:46 AM

Then I wonder why insulin is NOT the first choice of treatment... Is it more costly?  Are people on insulin also put of high blood pressure pills to protect their heart and kidney.  If you don't take pills, then you wouldn't have to worry about the liver damage in the long run, am I right?  Hmmmm...  I wonder...

 

When I requested insulin instead of orals my doctor was delighted, she said it really was the best thing for me.  Regardless of how much insulin your body makes, injected insulin uses a different pathway and is more effective when insulin resistance is an issue. 

 

Doctors don't prescribe it more because a lot of people are afraid of it or needles or both.  Many people also look upon it as a sign of failure, which it isn't really.  Insulin also requires more testing to get the proper dosage, it's not like just popping a pill.  There's also the litigation, doctors are afraid of people suing them because of lows.    Insulin has a non-deserved bad reputation.

 

I don't know what you mean about not having liver damage if you don't take pills?????

 

Lizzy

‎03-24-2012 12:49 AM

annieO wrote:

Question:  I will probably be having surgery soon and I don't take

insulin. I just take pills for my Type II. I know protocol is to give

insulin if blood sugar reaches 175.  Should I be okay with this,

or should I request I not be given the insulin unless I reach a higher

number, say 200 or 250? Or am I better off having the insulin given to me.

 

Thanks!

 

AnnieO

Hi Annie,

 

Sorry about the surgery.  I'd go with the insulin.  The better your numbers are the quicker you'll heal.  Don't worry, they won't give you a large dose because they don't want your numbers too low.

 

With the meals that hospitals serve, you'll need insulin!

 

Lizzy

Knowledge is Power!

Re: Insulin for surgery?

‎03-24-2012 01:08 AM

HI Annie, You've received some great responses already. I'm not a doctor, and I do not give medical advice. That said, just a head's up . . . you may already know this, but stress [any kind of stress] on the body can make your sugars go up. Surgery is a stress on the body. Therefore, do not be surprised if your sugars do go up some. As you know, well controlled sugars aid in optimal healing. If it were me, I would discuss this w/ my doctor and the anesthesiologist ahead of time also. Personally, if it were me, I would opt to abide by what my physician deemed most appropriate for me. If you have any questions or concerns, may I suggest you write them down on a paper before speaking with your doctor{s} - that way, you can be sure all your questions are answered. Wishing you a speedy recovery! Sincerely, RB
